description.text: Contains the wireless communication aspects of the asset.

hardware and software implementation of algorithms for wireless communication (VDI/VDE 2185 Part-4, 2019).  Describes the parameters of the wireless communication function. This includes parameters of the transmitter and receiver. Moreover information about intances that implement the communication function (e.g. modules) can also be descrebed here.
This parameter describes the cycle with which the communication stack executes requests from the application and the wireless medium in ms.
It includes the name of the technology, the release/version and other informaton.

The media access control ensures for example that a communication request is served as far as the medium is free (CSMA) or it allocates the request to well defined time slots (TDMA). Combinations of these two as well as other access mechanisms are possible.
It describes which technique is used for accesing the rado medium. It can be for example CSMA or TDMA. It highly depends on the Technology.
Depending on the mediung access type, the  slot configuration can be descrided as number of slots for downlink, uplink and shared slots.
Number of timeslots reserved for downlink communication.
Number of timeslots reserved for uplink communication.
Number of timeslots that are reserved for downlink and uplink communication.
This parameter specifies how the security objectives of the application are met by the implemented security mechanisms
It describes the role of the asset has in the network: accespoint, end node, repeater. It could also be an immaterial asset as an heatmap, or a wireless communication manager
It describes the characteristics of radio channel as frequency, band, bandwidth.

Contains information related with the frequency band used by the asset. It refers to a range of frequencies within the electromagnetic spectrum, which includes all frequencies of electromagnetic radiation. Different technologies and applications often use specific frequency bands for communication.
List of bands that can be configured on the asset.
ID of current configured band.
Center frequency in MHz of the current configured band.

Bandwidth in MHz of current configured band. Bandwidth is the difference between upper cut-off frequency and lower cut-off frequency. The bandwidth is the range of frequencies occupied by a modulated carrier signal.
Refers to a specific channel of frequencies used for wireless communication. Radio communication technologies divide the spectrum into channels.

Most wireless technologies assign numbers to the specified radio channels. This parameter lists the specified numbers.  It may be used for some technologies (e.g bluetooth). Blacklisting can be considered.

Centre frequency is the geometric mean of lower cut-off frequency   and upper cut-off frequency of a radio channel. This parameter assigns the centre frequencies to the radio channels. It serves to specify the utilized frequency, crucial for systems like Wi-Fi. However, in instances of channel-hopping technologies like BLE, IOLW, and WirelessHART, where channels dynamically change, it's recommended to leave this property empty.

Bandwidth is the difference between upper cut-off frequency and lower cut-off frequency. The bandwidth is the range of frequencies occupied by a modulated carrier signal. The data rate of reliable communication is directly proportional to the bandwidth of the signal used for the communication.
Set of parameters that describe the quality of reception. The availabitly of these parameter depends on the technology and implementations.
It is a string that describes the parameter type depending on the technology.

The range delimits the limits that define the extent of acceptable values or conditions for the parameter. In the context of a reception quality indicator, one of the thresholds can typically be defined by the reception sensitivity parameter of some wireless modules.
It is the value specified during the desing phase.
It is the value configured In the commissioning phase.
It is the last received signal strength value stored by the communication module.

The transmit power is determined by the RF schematic of the wireless module. Depending on the wireless technology, standard or implementation it is fixed, adjustable in steps or free configurable. (VID/VDE 2185 Part4)
It is a string that describes the parameter type depending on the technology.

The range delimits the limits that define the extent of acceptable values or conditions for the parameter. In the context of output power, it is typically defined by the maximum transmit power of the transceiver.
It is the value specified during the desing phase.
It is the value configured In the commissioning phase.
It is the last received signal strength value stored by the communication module.
A set of parameters that include the information about the license holder as well as the contact person.
Official name of the applying/responsible company
Name of the responsible person
First name of the responsible
Official company address
Phone number
Fax number (optional parameter).
Contact mail address (optional parameter)
Description of the intended use (Aproximately one page).
Type of license: trial operation, normal operation.
This list contains information about the used frequency or frequency ranges. Only one of the three fields must be filled in.
Frequency for operation in the radio spectrum, subject to license application.
Frequencies for operation in the radio spectrum, subject to license application.
List with “start frequency” and “stop frequency” for operation in the radio spectrum, subject to license application.
This list contains information on the period of use of the frequency ranges applied for.
Begin of operation Day
Begin of operation Month.
Begin of operation year
Duration of operation in Days
This list contains the geographical information of the fixed stations. Information must include both the postal and geographic address, as well as the height of the antennas.
Address of the location.
Geographic Position in East and North degree, minute and second
Altitide above sea level.
Altitude above earth's surface.
FixedStations/NumberOfStations/1/0
This list contains the information about the mobile station (used geographical area, number of mobile stations and kind of operation).
Region in which the mobile should be used.
Number of mobile stations.
One way or two way communication.
This list contains the technical parameters of the network.
Name or code of the equipment.
Manufacturer of the equipment.
Duplex Mode (FDD or TDD).
Access Mode e.g. FDMA
Type of Modulation e.g. FM
Used Bandwith in MHz.
Transmitter output power in dBm e.g. 10dBm
Antenna Gain in dBi respectively antenna pattern.
Polarisation of the antenna e.g. horizontal, vertical, …
Azimut of the antenna.
Elevation of the antenna.
Connection between radio system and other telecommunication systems.
Information about the time and status of application
Date of application submission.
Date of response from regulatory authority.
Response from the regulatory authority. Application approved/Application approved subject to compliance with conditions/Application rejected
Conditions so that the license application is accepted. e.g. restriction of transmission power, alignment of the antenna
Set of parameters that describe hardware aspects of the asset such as antenna type, connectors and interfaces during different life cycle phases.
It describes the antenna used for the wireless asset. (Monopole antenna, directional antenna, dipole antenna, special antenna). It defines also the antenna connector.
It defines how many antennas the asset has.
Connector type of the antenna.
Height of the antenna.
It describes the interfaces that the asset has: Ethernet, USB, Wireless, Digital IO, etc..
It contains information needed for device authentication. It is required to verify the legitimacy of devices and ensuring secure network access.

It is a parameter for device authentication in networks. It varies across wireless technologies, serving as a unique data piece presented during authentication, such as 5G's "Access Point Name," Bluetooth's "Master ID," and Wi-Fi's "SSID."
Cryptographic codes or credentials used alongside the Authentication Identifier.
